explanation:
- OS_ObjectIdGetById: The controlling expression depends directly on the return value assigned from this call. Its implementation (or at least its specification/possible return values and relation to the input var_id) is required to determine whether the value can vary or is invariant.
- OS_CondVarWait_Impl: Although only called when the condition is true, understanding whether this call (or its absence) can influence observable behavior or be inlined/optimized is useful; its prototype/semantics confirm it does not affect the controlling expression invariance.
- OS_SUCCESS: The constant used in the controlling expression. Its value and definition are required to evaluate the comparison and to know whether it could equal the return from OS_ObjectIdGetById in all cases.
- OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE: Argument passed to OS_ObjectIdGetById; its value/semantics could influence OS_ObjectIdGetById behavior and therefore whether the return value is variant.
- OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONDVAR: Argument passed to OS_ObjectIdGetById; its meaning affects the lookup logic and thus the variability of the return value.
- osal_id_t: Type of var_id. Its range/representation (e.g., typedef, special invalid values) can affect whether OS_ObjectIdGetById can return different results for different inputs.
- OS_object_token_t: Type of token output by OS_ObjectIdGetById; its representation and whether the token parameter can affect return behavior (e.g., via null pointer checks) may bear on whether OS_ObjectIdGetById always returns the same code.
- int32: The return type used in the function and by OS_ObjectIdGetById / OS_CondVarWait_Impl; knowing the exact typedef ensures correct interpretation of constants and comparisons.

Providing these symbols (implementations or precise specifications/headers) lets the analyzer determine whether the if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS) test can be invariant (always true/false) or is genuinely dependent on input/state, which is required to assess compliance with the MISRA rule.
